Exercise 

Which of the following identities are correct?

generalfeedback.text:
Note the following.

\( \sinh(2x) = \sinh (x+x) \), so using the formula for \( \sinh(x+y) \) with \( y = x \) we obtain \( \sinh(2x) = 2 \sinh x \cosh x \).

\( \cosh(2x) = \cosh (x+x) \), so using the formula for \( \cosh(x+y) \) with \( y = x \) we obtain \( \cosh(2x) = \cosh^2 x + \sinh^ 2 x \).

Recall that \( \cosh^2 x - \sinh^2 x = 1 \) (previous key point) which implies \( \sinh^2 x = \cosh^2 x - 1 \), so combining with the formula for \(\cosh^2 x\) just obtained above we get \[ \cosh(2x) = \cosh^2 x + \sinh^ 2 x = \cosh^2 x + ( \cosh^2 x - 1) = 2 \cosh^2 x - 1.\]

Also, \( \cosh^2 x - \sinh^2 x = 1 \) (previous key point) implies \( \cosh^2 x = 1 + \sinh^2 x\), so combining with the formula for \(\cosh^2 x\) just obtained above we get \[ \cosh(2x) = \cosh^2 x + \sinh^ 2 x = (1+ \sinh^2 x) + \sinh^2 x = 1 + 2 \sinh^2 x.\]

To see that each of the other identities is incorrect, specify a particular value for \(x\) for which the identity is wrong. Also note that they are inconsistent with the correct identities that are proved above.
